name: dklounge.github.com
body:
### About David

David Kim organizes [Ruby Rookies](http://rubyrookes.github.io/) and [Product Management Fast-Track](www.meetup.com/ProductLovers/) in San Francisco.

David previously was the head of business development at Hack Reactor. David interacts extensively with top-tier companies in the Bay Area. David is a life hacker who solves problems and enables people in the community.

David shares his experiences and musings on Medium and on blogger. You can follow him on Twitter: [@findinbay](http://www.twitter.com/@findinbay) or Github: [dklounge](http://github.com/dklounge/). Ask him a question on [Quora](http://www.quora.com/David-C-Kim), or join him on a long run with [Anyone Can Run San Francisco](http://www.meetup.com/RunningSF/).

### Highlights

* I'm excited to be hosting [Gregg Pollack of Code School](https://twitter.com/greggpollack) on 8/22 for a Ruby Rookies meetup to talk about [12 steps to becoming a better developer](http://www.meetup.com/sfruby/events/131917612/).
* I was excited to be featured on Startup Digest on 8/19 for my blog entry about forging ahead - [don't step back, step forward on Medium](https://medium.com/better-humans/d8f93537218d).

### How I spend my time

Here's how I spend my time. If you'd like to collaborate, please feel free to reach out to me. You can email me, David <daviddarden11@gmail.com>.

* Blogging at [findinbay](http://findinbay.blogspot.com/) - happy to discuss guest-blogging on business, technical education, and entrepreneurship.
* Consulting via [TalentTap](http://dklounge.github.io/TalentTap/) - do you need developers for your project? talk to me about it and see how I might help.
* Organizing [RubyRookies](http://rubyrookies.github.io/) - we are a grass-roots Ruby and Rails learners; let me know if you're interested in organizing an event and I will help with venue/speakers, etc. Also, please feel free to contribute to our [Ruby Rookies public repo](http://github.com/rubyrookies/).
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
